story:
We solicit your kind support for the Hourglass Literary Magazine, an annual and bilingual publication from Bosnia and Herzegovina. Hourglass aims to present to readers both emerging as well as established writers who write in English and the BCMS languages comprising Bosnian, Croatian, Serbian and Montenegrin. The magazine is staffed mostly by volunteers (most of them writers) from Former Yugoslavia, as well as from Spain, Hong Kong and United States, and is the first and (probably) the only literary journal from Bosnia and Herzegovina to have made it internationally, reaching readers across the globe. Hourglass Literary Magazine is also the first literary magazine from Bosnia and Herzegovina to become member of CLMP – [ c l m p ] – Community of Literary Magazines and Presses.

As we are aware that possible contributions come from your hard-working earned money, we have put together this proposal/pitch to provide to you the best possible perks (rewards) for your support, and although our campaign is based on magazine’s pre-orders, there are many perks (rewards) that can help us reach not only primary goal, but also our “stretched goal”.


IN SHORT

We strive – and this is our manifesto’s core – to mix voices in one polyphonic structure, i.e. to connect writers who write in English, whether as native English speakers or international, with authors who write in what it used to be one language – Serbo-Croatian – but is now, after the civil war, segmented into the four languages – Bosnian, Croatian, Montenegrin and Serbian.

Through the pages of the magazine we also aim to take a stand against all forms of violence and bigotry that attempts to infiltrate and override our collective sanity. Hourglass Literary Magazine’s manifesto’s can be found via our website.

The Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1 is awaiting final touches by our dedicated team of editors and staff members: Lana Bastašić, Lejla Kalamujić , Anirban Ray Choudhury, Jelena Lengold, Sibelan Forrester, John K. Cox Tea Tulić, Nemanja Mićević, Đurđica Bjelošević and Tanja Stupar-Trifunović.


PERKS/REWARDS (in short)

If you are already asking yourself how much it will cost and how do I help? – pre-ordering/subscription to Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1 is what we consider as our featured perk. As reward receive Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1 with shipping included.

Supporting Hourglass Literary Magazine, even if we don’t reach our campaign goal, will make it possible to sell the magazine at a lower price $15-17 + shipping and, again, note that right now, via our campaign, you can receive Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1 for $15 with shipping included, what more every perk (reward) comes with free shipping.

There are various choices/options for contributing towards our effort, with rewards ranging from a “Thank You” note on our website and social media or a “Thank You” note in our printed and digital editions to a bundle of books by and about Danilo Kis. Apart from individuals, academic institutions, libraries, bookstores and workshops as well as private schools, universities and commercial institutions are eligible to pre-order Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No.1.


HOURGLASS AND COMMUNITY

Our stretched goal is to organize literary festival and artist in residence program in 2017. At Hourglass Literary Magazine we feel responsible to contribute to community and writing communities. Literary festival and artist in residence program are very distinctive projects and we do not imagine that a crowdfunding campaign can cope with the costs of such events, but it can certainly help us to involve and financially encourage grant and technical writers, grant researchers, coordinators, social network managers, translators etc.

Our campaign will last for sixty (60) days, and there will be more perks announced every couple of weeks as we continue to collaborate with artists from around the globe. For instance Escola Bloom, a Spain based workshop, will happily read, edit and provide one to two hours Skype chat for an emerging writer who needs feedback on his writings (available now). Other interesting perks include postcards (currently in print) of old and contemporary Bosnia and Herzegovina with handwritten THANK YOU note.

(AVAILABLE NOW)

(Note: Perks with short description are on the right side of this page; to learn more about our perks/rewards in-depth, please find it within this page.)

HOURGLASS LITERARY MAGAZINE ISSUE NO. 1

(Un)like many other “crowdfunders” we are starting this campaign with results and achieved goals.

Hourglass Literary Magazine’s Issue No.1 featured authors are Philip Ó Ceallaigh, Irish short-story writer and the winner of Rooney Prize for Irish Literature in 2006, and David Albahari, Serbian writer residing in Calgary, Canada and a member of the Serbian Academy of Science and Arts. David Albahari has been the recipient of many literary awards and prizes, including the NIN Award (1996), Bridge Berlin Award (1998) and in 2012 Vilenica Prize.

The first issue of the Hourglass Magazine is dedicated to Danilo Kiš. Thanks to Danilo Kiš's ex-wife Mrs Mirjana Miočinović, we gained exclusive rights to be the first to print Danilo Kiš's unpublished works in English, including interviews, essays and short stories. Although Danilo Kiš's works were published in over thirty languages during his lifetime, Susan Sontag was probably first writer to introduce Kiš to a wider, global audience, editing the non-fiction works of Kiš in Homo Poeticus: Essays and Interviews. Subsequently, the award winning British historian Mark Thompson published Birth Certificate: The Story of Danilo Kiš; in 2013 this biographical piece was shortlisted for the National Book Critics Circle Award and later went on to be awarded the Jan Michalski Prize for Literature. And now at Hourglass Literary Magazine we strive to continue this rich saga and present this master's works to the widest audience possible.

Mark Thompson, along with Jasna Šamić, Filip David, Sibelan Forrester, John K. Cox and Gojko Božović will be contributing in the inaugural issue.

In the closing section, erudite writer and translator Brett Alan Sanders, and prominent author and LGBT activist Dragoslava Barzut, will be reviewing the latest global developments in the "Year Under Review".

Hourglass Literary Magazine’s contributors wrote for us, understood our concept well, discussed with us, even advised us and gave us their writings to be published and translated with no financial consideration! Perhaps, they are our true benefactors. 

II

Hourglass Literary Magazine ran an international writing competition which attracted 1200+ writers with more than 1500+ submissions in three categories – Best Short Story, Best Essay and Best Poem. Apart from writers who sent in their submissions from Former Yugoslavia, there have been submissions by authors writing in English from United States, Great Britain, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Ireland, France, Russian Federation, Sweden, Turkey, Germany, Austria, Spain, Czech Republic, Portugal, India, Greece, Italy, Netherlands, South Africa, Pakistan, Finland, Denmark, Norway, Poland, etc. The full list of countries as well as exact number of submissions will be announced once the jury is ready with the long list of accepted works in July 2016.

For 2015/2016 we have managed to provide $5000+ in total prizes to our contestants. This is thanks to the following  benefactors


Information about our finished contest – can be found here.

HLM FORMAT

Hourglass Literary Magazine is experimental in style and form, and we intend to be different from issue to issue. As an annual magazine, there is enough space and time for us to explore creative possebilities, and as long as it is literally and/or artistically challenging, we will consider changes to the layout, the design, and the format among other things.


Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1 has 220 pages; it comes in 8x15 inches format and print runs 2000 copies; first issue will not feature any photographs and will maintain a minimalistic, clean layout, illustrated by one-line drawings neatly combined with text.

All texts featured in magazine will be translated from English to BCMS and vice versa, and it starts with Hourglass, an Experiment, an introduction written by the Editor-in-Chief, Vojislav Voki Erceg.

Content:

  • Opening section – Philip Ó Ceallaigh (autobiographical sketch and essay) and David Albahari (two short stories and interview).
  • A section dedicated to Danilo Kiš  with contributions from Mark Thompson (An Alphabet for Danilo Kis), Jasna Šamić (Recollections,), Filip David (Fragments), Sibelan Forrester (Getting to Know Danilo Kiš Over Many Years), John K. Cox (Danilo Kis and the Hungarian Holocaust: The Early Novel Psalm 44) and Gojko Božović (yet to be announced).
  • Short stories, poems and essays by finalists, honorable mentions and winners from Hourglass Literary Magazine’s writing contest.
  • Book Recommendations / Book Reviews.
  • Micro-fiction – ten “pieces” from authors who write in English/BCMS.
  • Editor's choice – non-fiction piece about Irfan Horozovic by Milenko Stojicic.

  • Closing section – “Year Under Review”, featuring Dragoslava Barzut (with an essay yet to be announced) and Brett Alan Sanders with an essay Small Graces.


PERKS/REWARDS (explained in-depth)

Every subscription to Hourglass Literary Magazine includes free shipping. We will begin dispatching Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No.1 beginning October 2016.

Subscription to the magazine (without donation)
$15.00
Receive both digital and print edition of Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1. Shipping included.

Subscription to the magazine (with donation)
$20.00
Receive both digital and print edition of Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1. Your name will be featured at our web page in the section “Addicted to Reading”; your name (optional, if you do not want to stay anonymous) can be linked to your personal or preferred web location.

Subscription to the magazine PLUS

$50.00

Special edition of the magazine (hardcover) + everything from the subscription to the magazine (with donation) perk/reward + your name will be published in our printed inaugural issue as well as on our web site in the section “Addicted to Reading” with your name linked to desired web location.

Limited to 25 subscriptions.

Subscription to the magazine PLUS/MINUS

$30.00.

Includes everything from the “PLUS” perk/reward, but instead of hardcover as a reward you will receive a paperback edition.

Limited to 25 subscriptions.

Learn more about Danilo Kiš #1

$25.00

Receive Homo Poeticus: Essays and Interviews, introduced and edited by Susan Sontag + Hourglass Literary Magazine No. 1 + everything from  subscription perks.

Learn more about Danilo Kiš #2

$35.00

Receive “Birth Certificate: The Story of Danilo Kis” by Mark Thompson + Hourglass Literary Magazine No. 1 + everything from subscription perks.

Learn more about Danilo Kiš #3

$50.00

Receive “Homo Poeticus: Essays and Interviews”, introduced and edited by Susan Sontag +  “Birth Certificate: The Story of Danilo Kis” by Mark Thompson + Hourglass Literary Magazine No. 1 and everything included in subscription perks. 


For libraries

$80.00

Subscribe to Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1 and receive 10 copies ($8.00 per copy). Only libraries are eligible. For choosing this perk your library will be listed in our web site section “Places where you can read Hourglass Literary Magazine”.

For institutions

$50.00

Subscribe to Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1 and receive 3 copies. Who is eligible? Basically, every institution, that has a library – academic institutions, publishing houses, writing schools/workshops and so on. For choosing this perk your institution will be listed in our web site section: “Friends”.

For bookstores #1

$70.00

Subscribe to Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1. Receive five copies for the price of $14.00, free shipping included; sell it, re-sell it for your own price. Name of your bookstore will be appearing in the section: “Where you can buy Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1”. Once you receive Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1 we will shout-out information about your bookstore via our social networks and newsletter to a community of 7000+ members. Also, apart from your bookstore’s logo you are optionally eligible to feature two pictures of your bookstore (exterior and interior).

For bookstores #2

$115.00

Everything included in perk: “For bookstores #1”. Receive ten copies.

For bookstores #3

$150.00

Everything included in the perks: “For bookstores #1 and #2”. Receive ten copies. In addition your bookstore will be featured at our website’s front page for three months.

Limited to three perks.


DONATIONS

The world of print magazines is highly competitive, and even established names require grants and donations to survive. Hourglass Literary Magazine is a magazine to support and nurture literary talent, and through your donations you can have your name inscribed in its future and in the future of so many talented, yet to be discovered writers.  

By donating to Hourglass Literary Magazine you can help us achieve our primary goal as well as “stretched goal” which will be explained later in the text. For every donation you will receive a copy of Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue No. 1. And, as we believe that donations should come from pure generosity and “literary awareness”, name of every donor will be featured at our web site in the section: “We couldn’t do it without you”. And this section featuring your name will remain on our website for as long as the website exists.

You can help Hourglass Literary Magazine by donating desired sum.

Buy us a coffee.

$5.00

Simply help us relax and do our job with less stress and anxiety.



Or you can select perk – on the right side of this page – and donate from $25 to $100.


TOWARD “STRETCHED GOAL”

Estimated at $15,000 ($7000), Hourglass Literary Magazine’s crowdfunding “stretched goal” is a completely new venture derived from Hourglass Literary Magazine’s mission. To take a further step towards bridging gaps between cultures, Hourglass Literary Magazine aims to hold the first international literary festival in Bosnia and Herzegovina which will amalgamate with the awards ceremony and will feature:

·  Book promotions by established authors.

·  Workshops.

·  Readings (by contestants as well as by established authors).

·  Musical events and art exhibitions.

·  Debates / round tables.

We hope to welcome you “at the confluence of the East and the West”, in Bosnia and Herzegovina next year (2017).

II

It is planned that Hourglass Literary Magazine’s ARTIST IN RESIDENCE program will host both emerging and established writers; the attendees will be guests of awards ceremony and literary festival. ARTIST IN RESIDENCE should cover:

·  One month in one of Croatia’s cities.

·  Airline ticket and full hospitality.

·  Access to library.

·  Host, and, most importantly, place to write free, without distractions.

SPONSOR ARTIST

Sponsor Hourglass Literary Magazine’s writer in year 2017.

$500

Limit: 10 perks.

BECOME SPONSOR/BENEFACTOR

Sponsor one of Hourglass Literary Magazine’s upcoming events in 2017.

$1000

Limit: 5 perks.

BECOME OFFICIAL SPONSOR

Become Hourglass Literary Magazine’s officials ponsor in 2017.

$5000

Limit: 1 perk.

FINAL NOTE

Hourglass Literary Magazine is run by writers and writers comprise the board, jury and editoral staff.

Our thoughts stumbled upon running crowdfunding campaign based on the magazine’s pre-orders, once we realized how many people visit our web site daily. Very soon we started to receive our first subscriptions and donations via the web site’s link (which was rather hidden than exposed).

Couple of months later, in one of our contestants’ cover pages we read:

While exploring your magazine’s website, I stumbled upon its manifesto, which I read with great interest. The Hourglass goal: “achieving international mélange” (originally intercultural mélange), particularly resonated with me… said one writer to whom we want to thank for allowing us to quote excerpt from his submission cover page.

So, it was not surprising to receive such letters of support:


Now, we have a complete list of contributors, and as the jury evaluates 1500+ submissions from 1200+ authors from all around the globe, as translators and proofreaders pore over texts, Hourglass Literary Magazine’s impact is quite obvious. We believe it could, it should, it must be more powerful.

Risk & Challenges

We chose Indiegogo and its flexible feature to avoid unnecessary risks – every reader is important to us. Our confidence led us here; now we want to step “into tomorrow” to bring to you an even better magazine. Remember that by pre-ordering, donating and so on we are building Hourglass Literary Magazine’s future together as we head into 2017 with a strong subscriber base.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us by sharing this campaign via Twitter or Facebook, simply use Indiegogo share tools:

Stay with us, follow us via:



THANK YOU!

residing in Calgary, Canada and a member of the Serbian Academy of Science and
Arts. David Albahari has been the recipient of many literary awards and prizes,
including the NIN Award (1996), Bridge Berlin Award (1998) and in 2012 Vilenica
Prize.
The first issue of the Hourglass
Magazine is dedicated to Danilo Kiš. Thanks to Danilo Kiš's ex-wife Mrs Mirjana Miočinović,
we gained exclusive rights to be the first to print Danilo Kiš's unpublished works in
English, including interviews, essays and short stories. Although Danilo Kiš's
works were published in over thirty languages during his lifetime, Susan Sontag
was probably first writer to introduce Kiš to a wider, global audience, editing
the non-fiction works of Kiš in Homo
Poeticus: Essays and Interviews. Subsequently, the award winning British
historian Mark Thompson published Birth
Certificate: The Story of Danilo Kiš; in 2013 this biographical piece was
shortlisted for the National Book Critics Circle Award and later went on to be
awarded the Jan Michalski Prize for Literature. And now at Hourglass Literary Magazine we strive to continue this rich saga
and present this master's works to the widest audience possible. 
Mark
Thompson, along with Jasna Šamić, Filip David, Sibelan Forrester, John K. Cox
and Gojko Božović will be contributing in the inaugural issue.
In the
closing section, erudite writer and translator Brett Alan Sanders, and
prominent author and LGBT activist Dragoslava Barzut, will be reviewing the
latest global developments in the "Year Under Review".

Hourglass
Literary Magazine’s contributors wrote for us, understood our concept well,
discussed with us, even advised us and gave us their writings to be published
and translated with no financial consideration!
Perhaps, they are our true benefactors. 
II



Hourglass Literary Magazine ran an
international writing competition which attracted 1200+ writers with more than
1500+ submissions in three categories – Best Short Story, Best Essay and Best
Poem. Apart from writers who sent in their submissions from Former Yugoslavia, there
have been submissions by authors writing in English from United States, Great
Britain, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Ireland, France, Russian Federation, Sweden,
Turkey, Germany, Austria, Spain, Czech Republic, Portugal, India, Greece,
Italy, Netherlands, South Africa, Pakistan, Finland, Denmark, Norway, Poland,
etc. The full list of countries as well
as exact number of submissions will be announced once the jury is ready
with the long list of accepted works in July
2016.

For 2015/2016 we have
managed to provide $5000+ in total
prizes to our contestants. This is thanks
to the following  benefactors





Information about our
finished contest – can be found here.

HLM FORMAT

Hourglass Literary Magazine is experimental in
style and form, and we intend to be different from issue to issue. As an annual
magazine, there is enough space and time for us to explore creative possebilities,
and as long as it is literally and/or artistically challenging, we will
consider changes to the layout, the design, and the format among other things.




Hourglass Literary Magazine Issue
No. 1 has 220 pages; it comes in 8x15 inches format and print runs 2000 copies; first issue will not feature any photographs and will maintain a
minimalistic, clean layout, illustrated by one-line drawings neatly combined
with text.




All texts featured in magazine will be
translated from English to BCMS and vice versa, and it starts with Hourglass, an Experiment, an introduction
written by the Editor-in-Chief,
Vojislav Voki Erceg.


Content:


Opening section – Philip Ó
Ceallaigh (autobiographical sketch and essay) and David Albahari (two short stories and interview).

A section dedicated to Danilo
Kiš  with contributions from Mark
Thompson (An Alphabet for Danilo Kis),
Jasna Šamić (Recollections,), Filip
David (Fragments), Sibelan Forrester
(Getting to Know Danilo Kiš Over Many
Years), John K. Cox (Danilo Kis and
the Hungarian Holocaust: The Early Novel Psalm 44) and Gojko Božović (yet to be announced).


Short stories, poems and essays
by finalists, honorable mentions and
winners from Hourglass Literary Magazine’s writing contest.

Book Recommendations / Book
Reviews.
Micro-fiction – ten “pieces” from
authors who write in English/BCMS.

Editor's choice – non-fiction piece about Irfan Horozovic by Milenko Stojicic.


Closing section – “Year Under
Review”, featuring Dragoslava Barzut (with an essay yet to be announced) and
Brett Alan Sanders with an essay Small
Graces.

story:
My Goal:

I've progressed myself significantly as a writer and a person in the past year. Much pain has been brought to me, alongside experience; a trait which I believe can make a writer great. I have created a world in this screenplay and my wish is to share it with the world, to provide touching influence to the people of my community. I have applied for a stand in the Harrisburg Flea, an independent monthly flea market held in Harrisburg, PA for local artisans to share their beloved work. Any support would help me greatly to cover costs of copyrighting, printing (along with original artwork by Joelle Hitz), and distributing the script to anyone who wishes to read it. I would be so happy to use this funding to benefit my passion for writing. If you wish to help my cause, I would be forever grateful for your generosity. 

Synopsis:

Samuel Anderson, a professor of Science and Technology, lives mostly alone in a spacious Pennsylvanian Estate. Besides himself, all that keeps him company is a stunningly lifelike Artificial Intelligence by the name of Delilah. When new technology is invented to bring this creation to life, this script follows Samuel's relationship with his beloved companion. Pressure exists within the highly influential nature of the AI, as he must craft every move carefully to ensure the highest potential of her existence. Transitioning from romanticism to sex, the robot learns of the mechanics of love and lust and the difference between them. Flip through the epic downfall of Samuel's greatest creation in this thrilling script, sure to leave a moved heart long after reading.

story:
Nuestra Historia

El Concurso del año pasado fue posible gracias a las donaciones que recibimos a través de este concurso, en esta ocasión la publicidad nos ha permitido tener un pequeño financiamiento inicial, pero esperamos que con el apoyo de todos ustedes podamos llevarlo un paso adelante y darles a nuestros concursantes, un estímulo mas grande.


El Impacto

Con este premio deseamos estimular a los escritores de Ciencia Ficción de habla hispana y demostraremos que la comunidad de la Ciencia Ficción en español continúa comprometida con sus escritores y está interesada en leer mas historias en nuestro idioma.


¿Qué necesitamos y qué obtendremos?

Tenemos casi cuatro meses para conseguir un premio para nuestros escritores, 1000 dólares, es una meta ideal que dividiríamos entre los ganadores del siguiente modo, 500 dólares para el primer lugar, 300 dólares para el segundo lugar y 200 dólares para el tercer lugar.

Pero ¿Qué pasa si no alcanzamos la maravillosa cifra de los 1000 dólares? No importa, dividimos cualquier cantidad que se consiga recolectar entre los ganadores de una forma similar a la descrita arriba, recordemos que Indie GOGO nos entregará cualquier cantidad de dinero que hayamos recolectado ¡Incluso si recolectamos mas de lo pautado! :D

Entre mas dinero consigamos recabar, tanto mas estimulados se sentirán los escritores, y entre mejores sean las historias, mas ganas tendrán los lectores de donar al premio :D



Nota: recordemos que Indie GOGO y Paypal se quedan con un mínimo porcentaje.


Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Para que esto funcione necesitamos ponernos en campaña, y promoverlo al máximo, de manera que todos los posibles participantes se enteren y se motiven a integrarse. Así que además de donar dinero tenemos que utilizar nuestras habilidades sociales para que la mayor cantidad de gente se entere de lo que estamos haciendo.

Así que cuéntaselo a los lectores de tu blog, enlaza el proyecto en tu perfil de facebook o díselo a tus seguidores de Twitter. Y no te olvides de votarnos en los agregadores como Bitacoras, o Reddit.

¡Muchas gracias de antemano! :D

story:
Short Summary

My Name is Tim I grew up in Watts,Compton and South Central Los Angeles.

I have finally decided to tell my story about how hard it was to be me, raised by a single parent in very dangerous, gang, drug, murder, infested citites. The things I had to do and overcome, in order to go to school, play football and attend practices while trying to make it out alive, earn a scholarship for free education and make it as a professional athlete,all while being undersized and in many cases alone. Contributors will help get a story out that needs to be told and seen. This is for athletes and parents with the same struggles. It's for fans of the sport or anybody curious enough to see what young men go through to survive and still accomplish a dream. Its Inspirational and very Educational. If you are clueless to what your talented son has done or is doing as an athlete or young man in the streets, this movie is for you. If you have a daughter that seems to gravitate to these athletes this movie is for you too. It will uncover many things that go on within the streets and athletic lives of young men and women from the ground level to the top floor.It will also uncover the struggles of parenting these young men and women. This movie will also uncover the struggles of a professional athlete trying to make the cut, but the struggle and surrounding people are the same just on a higher level.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

I need $10000 to get the script written. All money will be paid to writer. If I dont reach targeted goal, all money will still still go to writer. I have an excellent writer with alot of industry experience. Her name is CAROLE PARKER who wrote FILLMORE starring SNOOP DOGG. We are very excited for this project, but as you will learn in the movie, most former professional athletes are done wrong and handled inproper, making life after football a nightmare. I am a full time student who just completed his MS in PE/Athletics & Sports Business Administration. I also Have A BFA in Media Production. I have been going to school for the past 10 years and surviving off of financial aid and a small highschool coaching job, while others who are already rich get richer talking about how they cheated after making money cheating. The time is now.

 

The Impact

Your contribution will help me in completeing a dream of getting a movie done that educates the world on street life combined with sports and the obsticles faced to succeed as an athlete. This will also help inspire those in a similar situation to continue to fight and prosper and pursue their dream. Also this film will open the eyes of nieve parents, coaches, and friends of the struggling about the participation of a son or daughter growing up in the streets and dealing with each other. Ask yourself as a parent, What is my son or daughter doing at school, at parties, with these athletes, how are they treated and treating each other? what are the coaches like? how do they help? etc

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help out financially, I would appreciate if you can help put the word out about this script/movie to any and everyone that may potentially help in the cause. I believe that this will be such a powerful eye-opening movie.

story:
Help us make great digital magazines!

We started Mag Monster to be able to do what we love the most: make magazines! And to be able to make as many magazines as we can, we have started this crowdfunding drive.


Update May 29th: Tweet about us or like us on Facebook and get a free special issue of the mag!

Okay, so our crowdfunder can probably use a bit of extra help. We have decided to add a few incentives for the people who would like to help us out. If you tweet about our crowdfunding drive, or like us on Facebook, you will get a free copy of the special Pixar issue of Animatonic, which we will release digitally in August. If you can get other people to tweet about us or like us on Facebook as well, then you will also get a free copy of the Animatonic Yearbook, which is coming out digitally at the end of the year. These special issues will normally retail for $3 (Pixar issue) and $5 (Yearbook).

We have also added an extra incentive for advertisers. You can buy a full page ad in one of our mags for $100, or you can buy our Ad Special for $200, which will not only give you a full page ad, but also a free 12 page digital mag about your product. You can decide what you will do with the mag, but we will also put it up on our website and promote it through our Twitter-feeds and mags. We are very dedicated to make Mag Monster a succes, so we hope you can take a few minutes of your time to help us out. Any help is greatly appreciated!

Update

Before we continue: the first issue of our free animation magazine Animatonic is now online! You can read it online by clicking here. Just click the link and automatically a magazine reader will open where you can read the mag. This works on any PC, tablet and smartphone.

Another update

We now have zero issues of both Heroics and Touch Gaming Magazine online. Check them out to see what you can expect from the full mags coming soon.

My name is Patrick Rijnders, and I made my first magazine with my friends when I was 9. We made one copy of it and went door to door in our neighbourhood, giving neighbours the opportunity to rent the mag for an hour. In case you are wondering: No, it wasn't a big success, but it started my love of magazines. Since then I have worked on dozens of mags, both as hobby and professionally.

Nowadays, over here in Holland (and probably also in other countries), it's difficult to get a job in the magazine business. More and more magazines get cancelled and publishers aren't really looking for people to come working for them. I was laid off when the company I worked for ended up in bad weather, and I haven't been able to work in magazine publishing since.  

Enter Mag Monster Publishing.

I decided to take matters into my own hands, and started this company to make the mags that I would love to read, and that I hope other people would like to read as well. I'm doing the editing, designing, part of the writing and making sure the mags get out there. I have a group of friends and ex-colleagues who are helping out by writing articles for me, and this way it's possible to make a magazine once every three weeks or so.

We're starting with three magazines, which are going to be published six times a year: Animatonic, Heroics and Touch Gaming Magazine. We're going to release a special yearbook for each of these three magazines as well, at the end of the year. Since life is expensive enough as it is, we're going to be giving our mags away for free. As we do need money to cover our expenses, we decided to set up this crowdfunding campaign.

To $ 3000, and beyond!

We need about $ 3000 to be able to make magazines for a year, and keep them free. This covers all our costs, plus we plan on using the money for a bigger, better website and our own dedicated IOS and Android apps. If we go beyond 3000 dollars, we plan to use the money to make the mags bigger, and to get more people involved so we can make even more magazines.

Support us for a unique prize!

For people supporting us, we have a unique offer, since three lucky people supporting us will get:

Your own personal digital magazine!

That's right, you tell us what you want in this 32 page issue and we make it for you. It can be about anything, as long as it's entertainment related. Do you want a magazine about your favorite actor? No problem. A mag about your favorite band? Obscure 80's shoot-em-ups only released in Japan? Movies starring people with beards? Actresses called Lucy? You name it, we make it. You will act as our editor (though we do have final say) and decide what articles we write. Or we can come up with ideas and you just give us the ok. And when the mag is done, you can do with it what you want. Keep it just for yourself? Sure. Share it with friends and family? Or put it online for everybody to read? You can even try to sell it if you want.

So, what mags are we going to publish?

 

Animatonic

We love animated movies, and if you love them as well this is the mag for you. Inside our pages you will find news, reviews and previews of the latest animated movies, with plenty of attention for the animated classics as well. We cover anything the big studios make but won't stop there. International and independent movies will get plenty of space as well. The first issue of Animatonic is online now, and you can read it here. It has an extensive look at Monsters University, previews of Epic, Turbo and more, reviews of The Croods, Wreck-It Ralph and classic Japanese anime My Neighbour Totoro, among others. We will update this page with info on where you can download it as soon as the mag is online. Issue 2 will be released on July 5th.

 

Heroics

Like Animatonic, but then all about superheroes. Superheroes in comics, in movies, on TV and anywhere we can find them. If it's superheroic, we'll cover it! Issue 1 will be released on June 3rd.

 

Touch Gaming Magazine

We actually already released two issues of Touch Gaming Magazine as an iPad-exclusive magazine two years ago, and now it's back, with news, reviews, previews and interviews, all about gaming on your tablet! We cover IOS, Android and Windows Mobile gaming. The latest issue will be released on June 17th, followed by another issue on Augustus 9th.

Support us and we will keep making magazines for you 

All the money we make with the mags is going to be spent on making Mag Monster grow. Besides, it will keep us off the streets and doing what makes us happy: Make mags for you! And if we don't reach our goal, that won't be the end for Mag Monster Publishing. We're going to continue to make mags for as long as we can go on.

A little bit more about me

Even if you have become interested in reading the magazines, you probably want to know a little bit more about me before you decide to support Mag Monster Publishing. I'm a 40 year old editor from the Netherlands. I'm married, have two kids and have been working in the magazine business for over 20 years. I studied in Amsterdam at the Hogeschool van Amsterdam. The study was called Redactie/Productie, which translated means Editing and Producing (magazines and books).

After school I worked for NFL Europe team Amsterdam Admirals, for whom I made all their publications (magazines, newsletters, media guides) for two years. After that I worked as a journalist, working for several local papers and a handful of magazines. I then rolled into magazine publishing, working as editor, deputy editor and writer on literally dozens of magazines and websites, including SF Report, Home Entertainment Today, CompuKids, PC Active, Webber, D-Zone, DVD World and many, many more. During my later years I also worked as translator, translating UK magazines for the Dutch market.

Next to my full-time jobs, I have tried my hand at doing my own thing several times. I was co-founder and editor of one of the first Dutch websites on gaming, GameNed, as well as editor and head writer for movie website Movie Scribblings. I had a website about animation called Animated Chatter and launched Touch Gaming Magazine and Animatonic two years ago. Throughout those years I have worked with many talented writers, several of whom will be working with me on the Mag Monster magazines.

 

Wait!

Oh, you want more info on our special prizes? Yes, when this crowdfunder has reached it's end, we will pick three names out of all the people who supported us, no matter which perk you chose, and then we will work together on making something fantastic. For the record though: We won't make anything with hate, pornography and all that other nasty stuff you really don't want to read about.

 

So?

I hope this has convinced you to support Mag Monster Publishing. I want nothing more than to make great mags for you. So please support us and let your friends and family know about us :)
story_txt:
Help us make great digital magazines!
We started Mag Monster to be able to do what we love the most: make magazines! And to be able to make as many magazines as we can, we have started this crowdfunding drive.

Update May 29th: Tweet about us or like us on Facebook and get a free special issue of the mag!
Okay, so our crowdfunder can probably use a bit of extra help. We have decided to add a few incentives for the people who would like to help us out. If you tweet about our crowdfunding drive, or like us on Facebook, you will get a free copy of the special Pixar issue of Animatonic, which we will release digitally in August. If you can get other people to tweet about us or like us on Facebook as well, then you will also get a free copy of the Animatonic Yearbook, which is coming out digitally at the end of the year. These special issues will normally retail for $3 (Pixar issue) and $5 (Yearbook).
We have also added an extra incentive for advertisers. You can buy a full page ad in one of our mags for $100, or you can buy our Ad Special for $200, which will not only give you a full page ad, but also a free 12 page digital mag about your product. You can decide what you will do with the mag, but we will also put it up on our website and promote it through our Twitter-feeds and mags. We are very dedicated to make Mag Monster a succes, so we hope you can take a few minutes of your time to help us out. Any help is greatly appreciated!
Update
Before we continue: the first issue of our free animation magazine Animatonic is now online! You can read it online by clicking here. Just click the link and automatically a magazine reader will open where you can read the mag. This works on any PC, tablet and smartphone.
Another update
We now have zero issues of both Heroics and Touch Gaming Magazine online. Check them out to see what you can expect from the full mags coming soon.
My name is Patrick Rijnders, and I made my first magazine with my friends when I was 9. We made one copy of it and went door to door in our neighbourhood, giving neighbours the opportunity to rent the mag for an hour. In case you are wondering: No, it wasn't a big success, but it started my love of magazines. Since then I have worked on dozens of mags, both as hobby and professionally.
Nowadays, over here in Holland (and probably also in other countries), it's difficult to get a job in the magazine business. More and more magazines get cancelled and publishers aren't really looking for people to come working for them. I was laid off when the company I worked for ended up in bad weather, and I haven't been able to work in magazine publishing since.  
Enter Mag Monster Publishing.
I decided to take matters into my own hands, and started this company to make the mags that I would love to read, and that I hope other people would like to read as well. I'm doing the editing, designing, part of the writing and making sure the mags get out there. I have a group of friends and ex-colleagues who are helping out by writing articles for me, and this way it's possible to make a magazine once every three weeks or so.
We're starting with three magazines, which are going to be published six times a year: Animatonic, Heroics and Touch Gaming Magazine. We're going to release a special yearbook for each of these three magazines as well, at the end of the year. Since life is expensive enough as it is, we're going to be giving our mags away for free. As we do need money to cover our expenses, we decided to set up this crowdfunding campaign.

We need about $ 3000 to be able to make magazines for a year, and keep them free. This covers all our costs, plus we plan on using the money for a bigger, better website and our own dedicated IOS and Android apps. Your own personal digital magazine!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Barbara Bacca. I have worked as a freelance translator for 20 years. I am currently writing my PhD dissertation about censored poetry in the former German Democratic Republic. Writing has always been one of my great passions. I have written stories and poems for about 25 years, out of pure passion. I don't want to leave them sitting in old diaries, in binders, or left to die inside a file, if they can serve a purpose. 

My dream is to create a website to raise awareness of sharing, compassion, and respect for every living being as the moral duty of every person and a priceless opportunity for human and social growth. This website will have a section for informational and news articles on the subject as well as an e-shop to sell previously unpublished e-books and audiobooks of stories, poems, and meditative writings on various topics, written by me. The topics of my writings are very diverse, but they are developed in the spirit of the ideals that are the life of my project.

OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT:

a) 51% of the proceeds from the sale of every item will be donated to a non-profit association that gives aid and protection to the needy or to animals. Each customer can choose from a list of associations to decide where his or her donation will go.

Each e-book and audio book will be translated and sold in at least 6 languages: English, French, German, Italian, Russian, and Spanish.

The website will include a discussion and informational blog, as well as a page that provides updates on the activities of the associations that receive donations, as well as complete information on the associations themselves.

Each title will have a unit price of $1.99 to $3.99. 51% of this amount will be donated to the association chosen by the customer.

The remaining sum will largely go to cover costs to maintain and update the site, to organize awareness events, and for the translation and creation of new e-books and audiobooks.

b) Along with providing material aid to these associations, there is also a mental and spiritual objective. The message that I want to communicate and foster is that the hierarchical classification of suffering according to the being who is victimized is a castration and a debasement of our potential for human growth. Life is precious in any form, and the suffering of living beings is always a tragedy, whether translated to a yelp or sobs – a tragedy that we can help prevent and cure. My initiative will certainly not change the world, but I am convinced that it can plant a little seed: to draw attention to the suffering of the weakest and most defenseless creatures, to encourage people to respond to their needs, to want to study and get to know about worlds and contexts that they never paid attention to before.

The primary objective of this project is not my personal gain, because we can never be fully satisfied with our lives if we don't contribute to improve the world outside of our door. To free one's self from the “none of my business” mentality is the one unfailing way to a healthy and complete happiness.


WHY I NEED YOUR SUPPORT:

I have set my fundraising goal at $6,000 but this is an ongoing project. Please, help me meet my initial goal.

A short breakdown of the estimated costs:

$500 - logo design
$950 - website (blog and e-shop included)
$2,800 - Translation and proofreading of the first 4 titles
$1,000 - e-books creation + audiobooks recording
$300 - perks
7% + $25.00 - Indiegogo and credit card fees 

My stretch (middle) goal is $7,000. Help me hit that goal and I can cover all the fees and production & shipping costs and fund the Russian translation + the relevant e-books and audio books creation.



My engagement

In 2008, I watched a TV program that told of the terrible fate of little Oscar, a stray puppy who was beaten, tortured, sodomized, and buried alive by a group of boys. Oscar died a few days later from the terrible injuries he had suffered. For me, it was an enormous shock. Through this tragic episode, I discovered a world of pain and atrocity: homeless animals, vivisection, zooerasty, factory farming, exploitation of animals – for food or not – and the grave indifference of humans to the tragedies of the animal world. The story of Oscar changed my life forever: at times it is more bitter, since the injustices and cruelties I am aware of are infinitely greater, but my life is also more rich with moments of joy, since I have developed the capacity to observe the world on a microscopic scale, taking in the beauty and the value of life in all its forms, and experiencing the joy of respecting it and becoming familiar with it. The compensation for this tenderness is unimaginable, and I want everyone to discover it. It is an experience that can't help but grab hold of your heart. By the end of January 2014 I am going to found a voluntary, non-profit association, Humanimalize, which I intend to use to build a worldwide network of people to introduce the mindset and deep human and social values of being open to every form of life, in the most diverse environments, and through training events, conferences, awareness demonstrations, and initiatives for voluntary aid to the needy. The project was created in a few days, but everyone involved is very excited about its potential.

At present I do my best to spread the concept of compassion also through my radio show, “L’Urlo Animale (The Animal Cry),” broadcast every week on the non-profit Italian web radio site www.radiolivemusic.com, my blog at www.barbarabacca.com, and the Facebook group against zooerasty that I co-administer. The name of the blog created by this group is "notosexualabuseofanimals.wordpress.com. “

Why do I think that people with different objectives meeting on one site has social benefits?

Some of the most severe problems afflicting the world come from irresponsible extremism. This includes the inclination to give protection based on sterile and discriminating criteria, specifically: disdain for animal rights activists by those who say we should be caring for people instead of animals, and some fringe elements of the animal rights movement who claim that animals are superior to humans. In this case as well, the middle path is the virtuous one. All extremism leads to a dangerous blindness, and takes energy away from what, in my humble opinion, is the only healthy battle: the fight for compassion without limits. What hinders this is the tendency to handle diversity with an instinct to separation and classification. But innocence, fragility, and the need for love and respect are not only for some categories of being, but for all living beings.

I believe and hope that bringing the world of humans closer to the world of animals and vice versa will encourage visitors to wonder about the reasons for such a joining, and perhaps to question their own personal classifications. The blog should then encourage and welcome helpful discussions, in the spirit of solidarity that the site should inspire in its visitors.

Hostility and fear are often the result of a lack of knowledge, or even of suffering. I would like to bring people together to encourage understanding and contribute to creating moments that enrich the givers at least as much as the associations to which they donate.

Over time, I have come to understand that the highest gift a human being can receive is compassion; a gift that is instilled and cultivated through attention to the most needy and defenseless creatures. Helping, understanding, and loving without discrimination makes us better, more mature, sensitive, and empathic human beings.


                    SOME OF THE ASSOCIATIONS RECEIVING DONATIONS
                                             (The list will be much longer) 

In alphabetical order:

ANIMALS ASIA

https://www.animalsasia.org

Animals Asia is devoted to ending the barbaric practice of bear bile farming and improving the welfare of animals in China and Vietnam. We promote compassion and respect for all animals and work to bring about long-term change. The Animals Asia team has been rescuing moon bears since 1994 and is the only organisation with a bear sanctuary in China.


CHILD SOLDIERS

http://www.child-soldiers.org/

Child Soldiers International is an international human rights research and advocacy organisation. We seek to end the military recruitment and the use in hostilities, in any capacity, of any person under the age of 18 by state armed forces or non-state armed groups. We advocate for the release of unlawfully recruited children, promote their successful reintegration into civilian life, and call for accountability for those who unlawfully recruit or use them.

DESTINY RESCUE

http://www.destinyrescue.org/

Destiny Rescue rescues children from red light districts, brothels and sexually abusive situations. Destiny Rescue provides rescued children the intensive care and love they need to recover from the traumatic effects of sexual abuse and sexual exploitation. We provide them medical help, counseling, schooling, vocational training and all daily needs required to be integrated back into society successfully. 


LIDA OLBIA

http://www.lidaolbia.it/

L.I.D.A. (Italian League for Animal Rights) is an Italian non-profit organisation working for animal rights. L.I.D.A.’s goal is to reduce the number of stray animals by rescuing and taking care of the many abandoned dogs and cats and by promoting and carrying out neutering projects. 


MEDECINS SANS FRONTIERES

http://www.msf.org/

Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is an international, independent, medical humanitarian organisation that delivers emergency aid to people affected by armed conflict, epidemics, natural disasters and exclusion from healthcare. MSF offers assistance to people based on need, irrespective of race, religion, gender or political affiliation.


SAFE HORIZON

http://www.safehorizon.org/

Safe Horizon is the nation’s leading victim assistance organization and touches the lives of more than 250,000 affected by crime and abuse each year. Whether we are responding to child abuse, domestic violence, or other violent crimes, we help victims and their families heal and rebuild their lives. 


SAVE THE DOGS AND OTHER ANIMALS

http://www.savethedogs.eu/

The association was born to give an answer to the tragic emergency that affects stray dogs in Romania, hundreds of thousands of animals exterminated every year by the authorities in a climate of general indifference and an endemic strayness, completely out of control.


THE BRIGITTE BARDOT FOUNDATION

http://www.fondationbrigittebardot.fr/ 

The Brigitte Bardot Foundation (Fondation Brigitte Bardot) is the leading animal protection NGO in France, with its own sanctuary in Normandy, Mare Azou, and alliances throughout the world to which FBB lends its considerable expertise and resources, to protect animals from exploitation and cruelty: from beagles in Croatia to Baby Harp Seals in Canada. It acts to heighten awareness, inform, relieve and save.


THE GRACIAS FOUNDATION

http://www.graciasfoundation.org/

“We empower vulnerable and impoverished women, children and young adults with holistic resources to lead dignified and sustainable lives”.


THE HUMANE SOCIETY OF THE UNITED STATES

http://www.humanesociety.org/  

The Humane Society of the United States is the nation’s largest animal protection organization, rated the most effective by its peers. Since 1954, The HSUS has been fighting for the protection of all animals through advocacy, education, and hands-on programs.

offers assistance to people based on need, irrespective of race, religion,
gender or political affiliation.

SAFE HORIZON
http://www.safehorizon.org/
Safe Horizon is the nation’s leading victim assistance
organization and touches the lives of more than 250,000 affected by crime and
abuse each year. Whether we are responding to child abuse, domestic violence,
or other violent crimes, we help victims and their families heal and rebuild
their lives. 

SAVE THE DOGS AND OTHER ANIMALS
http://www.savethedogs.eu/
The association was born to give an answer to the tragic emergency that affects stray dogs
in Romania, hundreds of thousands of animals exterminated every
year by the authorities in a climate of general indifference and an endemic
strayness, completely out of control.

THE BRIGITTE BARDOT FOUNDATION
http://www.fondationbrigittebardot.fr/ 
The
Brigitte Bardot Foundation (Fondation Brigitte Bardot) is the leading animal
protection NGO in France, with its own sanctuary in Normandy, Mare Azou, and
alliances throughout the world to which FBB lends its considerable expertise
and resources, to protect animals from exploitation and cruelty: from beagles
in Croatia to Baby Harp Seals in Canada. It acts to heighten awareness, inform,
relieve and save.

THE GRACIAS FOUNDATION
http://www.graciasfoundation.org/
“We empower vulnerable and impoverished women, children and
young adults with holistic resources to lead dignified and sustainable lives”.

THE HUMANE SOCIETY OF THE UNITED STATES
http://www.humanesociety.org/  
The Humane Society of the United States is the nation’s
largest animal protection organization, rated the most effective by its peers.
Since 1954, The HSUS has been fighting for the protection of all animals
through advocacy, education, and hands-on programs.

story:
Summary:

Hi.  My name is Jeanne and I've had more than 35 novels published under the names Jeanne Kalogridis and J. M. Dillard.  Because of illness and personal tragedy--and because I lost literally everything in the crash of 2008--I've been unable to work at my normal pace and am down to $0.  It'll take me until early summer to finish the book.  If I don't put in 10-hour days working on the novel, I face total financial disaster.  If you love historical novels, vampire novels or STAR TREK (and even if you don't), please help me pay the rent while I finish my current book!

A lot of fans have expressed concerns that this site is bogus.  Please feel free to contact me on my Facebook page (Jeanne Kalogridis), Twitter (@jkalogridis), or at jkalo@mac.com and ask whatever question you like.

  • What I Need & What You Get:

I need rent for March, April, and May, as well as funds to pay my phone bill and buy food, gas and medicine.  

  • $10,000 will pay three months' rent and phone, food, medications, some medical bills, and most importantly, dog food.  
  • I'm working on a fun, fast-paced, historically accurate novel about young pickpocket in Renaissance Florence (THE ORPHAN OF FLORENCE).  It's contracted for, and I need to make my deadline!
  • Even if I'm unable to reach my goal, I'll use the money for food and medications. And dog food for the sweetest Labrador in the universe, Django.
  • The Impact
  • Your contribution will allow me to finish the book that will pay future rent.  You'll be saving me and Django from homelessness, and that's no exaggeration.  
  • Feel free to Google me or check Amazon.com and see what other books I've written.  I'll make the deadline... I always do... I just need help this time to get there.  (P.S.  Like most writers, I make a middle-class living.  I'm not one of lucky rich few.  Although I can dream...)

  • Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can help me and Django by spreading the word.  Tweet, post, share.  And know that I'm grateful for any and all help.

If you have any doubt about the campaign's legitimacy, please feel free to email me at jkalo@mac.com and ask whatever questions you like to verify that I'm the one who posted this.

story:
Short Summary

Hi there. My name's Adrien Leduc, I'm 25 years old, and I want to put 25 copies of my book, The Dumnonian Hoard, into 25 children's hospitals and Ronald McDonald Houses across Canada and the U.S.

As a kid I loved reading. Adventure stories like those written by Enid Blyton. Hardy Boys. Harry Potter. Sigmund Brouwer. The Redwall series. Those great paperbacks you see at school book fairs and the ones you'd get as a gift from your teacher if you excelled at something. Creativity, imagination, making Disney moments in real life - that's what I'm all about and reading is a huge part of that.

In 1998, at the age of 11, I was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes. I spent a week in hospital and ever since, have been going to doctors, specialists and hospitals for check ups. For a young boy these trips can be frightening and intimidating. What made these trips tolerable was being able to read good books while there.

Kids going through tough things like diabetes, cancer and other illnesses should have access to books. Books take you places. Inspire you. Fuel your imagination and creativity. Even moreso for a child.

I've always felt an affinity for children - especially sick ones - and I feel like I have an opportunity to give back. That being said, my plan to become a "famous author" is still very much in its infancy and I don't have the financial means to get 25 copies of The Dumnonian Hoard printed up and sent out. While this book is available as an e-book and can be purchased on-line, I'd prefer to have paperback copies to send. Something a kid can hold and look at.

What We Need & What You Get

500 dollars will allow me to print and send out 25 copies. I'll use a low-cost, print on demand printer (Create Space or Lightning Source) to have 25 copies printed. (The average print cost for a paperback novel through Create Space and Lightning Source is five dollars per unit.) I am then budgeting the remaining 250 dollars (or what's left after I've had the books shipped to me from the printer's) for the postage to send the books out. Among the children's hospitals I hope to send copies to are the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario here in Ottawa, the Calgary Children's Hospital (where I spent time when I was diagnosed with diabetes), the Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto and the Morgan-Stanley Children's Hospital in NYC, as well as to Ronald McDonald Houses across Canada (and similar family hospices in the U.S.)

One dollar, two dollars, or ten dollars. Whatever you feel like giving will go a long way to making this happen.

The Impact

I've received excellent reviews for The Dumnonian Hoard and of all my books, I think it has the potential to be enjoyed by children of all ages.

Here's the synopsis:

Fourteen year old Sarah Rosenberg and her twin brother Joshua are spending the summer in France on an archaeological expedition with their Uncle Marty. However, what begins as a relaxing and fun-filled vacation quickly becomes a dangerous and harrowing adventure when the twins cross paths with a pair of ruthless antique smugglers. Will the twins find the treasure they seek before it's too late?

---

I really want to see my book end up on the shelves and on the library carts of children's hospitals and family hospices. I truly believe that this book will make a kid forget his/her issues for awhile and drop him/her smack dab in the middle of an adventure. Reading is so important. It opens doors to new things. Encourages learning. And a whole bunch of good stuff that you don't need to hear me go over here. If you enjoy reading - you can relate.

25 copies in 25 children's hospitals and family hospices across Canada and the U.S. If this works out and proves successful, I will GLADLY do this again in future, perhaps doubling the number of books next time.

I don't stand to make a penny from this, every dollar is budgeted towards printing and shipping. All I get from it is some free publicity - and that's enough for me. Most importantly, I'm giving kids the type of book that I enjoyed reading when I was in hospital or at the doctor's. I believe in this book and I think it will serve this purpose nicely. I hope you can help me reach this goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

Donate good quality kids' books / comics / graphic novels to children's hospitals and family hospices.

story:
My Story

A friend took the above video this summer when I was in Tokyo, but I never dreamed I'd be using it here.

Whenever people ask what I do for a living and I tell them I'm a travel writer, I always get the same reaction: "I wish I had your job!" While it's true that it has been an incredible ride and more than I ever imagined growing up in Kansas, I always tell people that the downside is money. I have been earning a living as a travel writer for more than 3 decades, first while living in Germany and hitchhiking everywhere I went and then driving my old beat-up Datsun from Canada to the Yucatan, selling my travel articles to newspapers across the US. I then moved to Tokyo in the mid-1980s and worked for a couple years as editor of a travel magazine. It was then that Frommer's contacted me about writing a guide book on both Japan and Hong Kong (it was to be their first venture in Asia). So I spent a year working on the project, six months traveling and six months writing. They paid me $7,000 for my efforts, and I made up the difference with my personal savings.

With a few exceptions when I was able to pick up extra well-paying assignments, I have lived below the poverty line ever since. It has been a conscious choice, because I am doing what I love. Over the years I have written or contributed to more than a dozen guide books (mostly Frommer's), and while they never paid much money, they at least kept me afloat if I added smaller assignments along the way. By living frugally and living below my means (I am a single mom and we live without air-conditioning or cable TV in a 1890s house I bought years ago for $90,000), I have been able to make it work.

Since 2008, however, and what the Japanese call the "Lehman Shock," many of my usual markets have dried up (including Frommer's USA, for which I covered Midwestern cities, and Frommer's Europe by Rail, for which I covered Germany and Austria). My Japan book long ago morphed into three books: Frommer's Japan, Frommer's Tokyo and Frommer's Hong Kong, all of which I update every two years and are now the bulk of what I do. Because the payments I receive to update them are so low; because--and this is the part that floors everyone--I am responsible for all my own travel expenses, and because my books are so time-intensive from start to finish, my guides pretty much ensure that my annual earnings are less than for a high-school graduate. 

Of course, then came the most terrifying natural disaster in my lifetime--the March 11 earthquake off the Tohoku coast of Japan, unleashing that massive wall of water that swept over villages, farms and people and in one instant changed absolutely everything in Japan. I have traveled so often along that coastline, that the triple disaster of earthquake, tsunami and nuclear meltdown seemed like it was happening right in my backyard. I had been planning to go to Tokyo in mid-March to update that guide book, but after the US travel advisory against traveling to Japan (which did more harm to Japan than good), the dramatic departure of foreigners, power blackouts and uncertainty of a nuclear radiation, I didn't make it there until May.The overwhelming message I hear from those who run small inns, hotels, restaurants, shops, and bars, is that the dramatic decrease in foreign visitors has been hurting them more than they'd ever imagined. Japan has always been a tough sell--expensive, far away, inscrutable in language and customs--but fears of earthquake and nuclear radiation have reduced tourism to historic lows. While no one has forgotten the disaster and never will, today it's the economy that dominates people's thoughts in Japan.

Japan needs travel writers and visitors more than ever. The kicker is that Japan has never been as expensive as it is now. The dollar has fallen 25% against the yen the past two years and is 40% less than it was 4 years ago. The result is that what was previously simply poverty wages for me has now become impossible wages. Although I get some help from the Japan National Tourism Organization (mostly rail passes) for which I'm very grateful, I have always paid for the bulk of my travels, including my flight to Japan, meals, buses, local transportation, admission to museums and attractions, and accommodations. For many years, I've felt that I've been promoting Japan entirely on my own.

But now, with decreased tourism and more than two decades of a depressed economy, Japan needs more than I can give. After running the numbers and trying to create a budget, I realized that unless I couch-surf (difficult at my age, let alone the size of Japanese apartments) or use money I've saved for retirement, there is no way I can pay for the seven months required to update Frommer's Japan.

That is why, for the first time, I am appealing to others to help make this book possible, including those who may not be traveling to Japan any time soon but would like to help in some tangible way. I feel that this is bigger than just me.

The Impact

Since October I have been working on the 11th edition of Frommer's Japan; my deadline is May 1. In that time I will make sure that every single fact in the 650-page book is updated. I just completed one month of travel in Japan, mostly to southern Honshu (places like Osaka, Himeji, Matsue, Hiroshima, Miyajima, and seven cities in Kyushu. I then flew north to Tohoku for my first trip to Hiraizumi, declared a World Heritage Site shortly after the earthquake; it's located in Iwate Prefecture, one of the hardest hit prefectures from the earthquake and tsunami. 

Without trying to sound boastful, I cannot overemphasize what an impact Frommer's Japan has on the cities it covers. Many people travel to destinations only covered in my guide, perhaps because travel in Japan is harder than in some other countries due to the language barrier. Because I am what one editor called "old school," I cover places in my book personally and rely on local recommendations for hotels, restaurants, etc., rather than the Internet or other guide books, and try to be fair in my reporting. I know that travelers depend on my information being correct; a bad guide book can ruin a vacation.

But it's hard doing justice to Japan, my readers, and myself when I'm limited because of finances. Of course, if I can't afford to continue doing the work I love, Frommer's can hire someone else to do it, since they own all the rights to my words. Someday, of course, I'll have to turn the reins over to someone younger, but I don't think now--when this guide book, already postponed, needs to come out as quickly as possible--is the time, not to mention that I have already given up so much financially to write and update these guides, it doesn't seem fair that in the end it's lack of money that prevents me from continuing. It doesn't seem fair that only people with an independent source of money or no financial obligations (house, kids) can afford to be travel writers.

What I Need to Update the Japan Guide

I'm being paid $24,000 for the Japan guide. $6,000 goes to an assistant I send to other parts of Japan, leaving me $18,000 to travel one month in Japan and live on until my May 1 deadline. The kicker, however, is that I get only half of the $24,000 as an advance. Since $12,000 is obviously impossible, I am adding $5,000 from my final payment for Frommer's Tokyo to make it through.

The budget I've come up with for $17,000 gives me:

1. $12,500 in living expenses from October until May (not quite $1,800 a month; obviously too low since my mortgage and self-employed health insurance total almost $1,500 a month, but I hope to augment it with other work when possible). As a single mother, I cannot jeopardize my children's welfare by going any lower on this amount.

2. $3,000 to an assistant (another $3,000 will be paid after our work is done and I get the second $12,000)

3. $1,500 for my flight to Osaka last month

4. ZERO money for my month of travel in Japan

In other words, not only does the guide fail to earn enough to live on, but it also leaves me nothing left over to actually go to Japan to do the job.   

During the month I just traveled in Japan, I spent less money than I ever have--just $2,000 (usually I spend $3,000). Everywhere I went, local tourist offices stepped up to the plate by showing me around (and usually buying my lunch and admission to local museums and sights); and some hotels and Japanese inns offered me a free room (some of them have been in my book for 10 or 20 years). Local prefectural tourist offices were so eager to show me new places (often smaller towns in the vicinity), I ended up working extra hard just to carve out a few extra hours for the new things. I worked 30 days straight without a day off, usually 10 hours a day. I usually left my hotel at 9am, returned around 7 or 8pm after a full day of walking and researching, and then spent the evening sorting brochures and notes, ansering emails, and planning for my next destination (I decided if I had to work that hard the rest of my life, I'd probably kill myself).

The bulk of my money spent in Japan went toward meals, hotels, and local transportation. To put things in perspective, a dormitory bed in a youth hostel costs about $41, a local bus ride costs $4, and the cheapest lunch special around $11 to $12. I, however, paid about $70 to stay at hotels I recommend in my book (and believe me, that was a bargain) and often paid $30 for dinner in my recommended "budget" restaurants. Sometimes I skipped lunch altogether; sometimes I had a rice bowl ($7) in a cheap fast-food restaurant instead of eating in one of my recommended restaurants (ideally I would actually eat at all the restaurants in my book every single edition, but that would cost far more than the $24,000 I earn for the guide).

In any case, due to the wonderful contributions from friends for this campaign (you guys rock!), I had to come up with just $1,200 of my own money for the trip, plus extra to make it through these first few months (I picked up one small writing job while on the road and just pitched another but it will be a while before I get paid for either). To do so, I had to pull $2,000 from my retirement account.

While it was fun but exhausting on the road, I now have the biggest bulk of my work ahead of me, including writing up all those new places I visited. I also got word this week that all Frommer's books are being revamped to make them more online friendly--certainly necessary, but a helluva lot of work for authors (without any additional pay).

I will get the second half of my Japan guide book payment in June or July, but by then I'll be working on Hong Kong, and because I'm not paid enough upfront for that guide either (about $6,000 for four months of work and three weeks in Hong Kong), I always have to use my Japan payment to last see me through that (just like I'm using Tokyo guide money to help me through the Japan book), and of course I'll also owe the assistant another $3,000.

In any case, this budget is all bare bones, so living on the edge, I can only hope that something unforeseen doesn't happen, like a car breakdown or a heater out, because there is no wiggle room in this budget. On the other hand, I'm used to living on the edge.

If you believe that Japan needs tourists now more than ever and that I should not personally go in the hole to update this edition of Frommer's Japan, I hope you will consider contributing if you can.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share with others--If you know people who have wanted to contribute to Japan's recovery or even perhaps people who have traveled in Japan with my guide, I hope you'll get the word out.
